Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WN0-W1C1-DXHJ-F1W7-00000-00EU plotting overhaul to rules governing tech giants2019-07-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:43:25ZLexisNexisEU plotting overhaul to rules governing tech giantsKeumarsA

The European Union (EU) has, for years, been incensed with the way social media firms have allowed harmful and illegal content to spread like wildfire across their networks. But officials in charge haven't quite settled on a concrete way of tackling this. 

Guidelines proposed by the European Commission nearly two years ago suggested a voluntary approach for tech companies in removing hate speech from their platforms. However, while social media sites have been digging their heels in, the threat of enforceable regulation has been growing.

See related 

In March last year, the European Commission outlined alternative plans giving these platforms just one hour to remove such content before imposing penalties.

The latest proposals, according to the Financial Times, involve literally rewriting the rulebook on how to engage with big tech. What's being dubbed the "Digital Services Act" is expected to give the EU a raft of legal powers to influence how social media platforms govern hate speech, extremist material and political advertising.

A concentration of power

The European Commission's latest proposals go so far as to wrestle away control from individual member states and funnel this power into a continental regulator.

According to Netz Politik, the German IT publication that originally broke the story, the new laws will substitute the older e-commerce directive, which stretches back to the year 2000. These legacy regulations are, quite simply, not fit for purpose in a modern age, and don't specify how they can be tailored to apply to the tech sector.

Under these new plans, however, officials will have the opportunity to craft sharper rules to fit around all facets of modern tech like cloud computing and social media. Provisions for online political advertising, especially, will have a newfound prominence given how concerned the EU has been about bad actors influencing online political discourse.

The most eye-catching aspect is certainly the creation of a new centralised EU tech regulator with enforcement powers. Where the EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) entrusted member states with statutory powers to fine organisations for violating strict   data protection principles, this will do the opposite.

Once the Digital Services Act comes into effect, member states will be required to repeal any domestic legislation regarding blocking content, or bring this in line with the EU's, partner with White & Case LLP Tim Hickman told IT Pro.

"The boundary between EU law and the domestic laws in this area is complex. In particular, the proposed Digital Services Act aims to tackle the problem of hate speech.

"However, much online speech is protected by the right to freedom of expression and information, in Article 10 of the European Convention on Human Rights, a treaty that the EU does not have the power to amend."

He added domestic laws regarding freedom of expression and freedom of information fall largely outside the EU's purview. This means approaches to tackling hate speech may yet diverge from one Member State to another.

The Brexit factor

The EU's moves could potentially scupper the UK's own plans to enforce regulation of online content, subject to the outcome of the Brexit fiasco and how closely the UK and EU will be regulatorily aligned.

After months of dithering and speculation, the Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport (DCMS) jointly-launched proposals with the Home Office in April outlining how the government plans to tackle these very issues.

If proposals outlined in the "Online Harms" white paper come to fruition, the government will establish a statutory regulator with powers to punish internet giants if they neglect to abide by a "duty of care". In extreme cases, the state regulator will disrupt companies' business operations and order internet service providers (ISPs) to block non-compliant digital services or apps entirely.

While the EU's plans aren't too dissimilar, under its model, proposals like these for national bodies will be overridden.

One reason for this could rest with the fact a number of member states have lately elected governments of a far-right persuasion, with Hungary and Italy being notable examples. Authorities in these countries may be less likely to be decisive on the spread of some forms of hate speech and disinformation across social media networks than this proposed legislation would require. Another reason could be that countries are simply lagging behind in the process of establishing ways of monitoring and regulating harmful content online.

Targeting big tech

These plans are nakedly aimed at companies like Facebook and Twitter, with these platforms often rampant with "fake news" and content deemed harmful.

The EU - and the UK - argue these companies have not been doing enough to get a handle on this issue. The likes of Facebook, Twitter and YouTube have, however, actually shown improvements in the way they tackle harmful content, with a European study published in February showing as much.

For instance, during a six-week period in 2018, 89% of flagged hate speech on platforms like Facebook, YouTube and Instagram were monitored within 24 hours, with 72% of this removed. This is in contrast to a previous study published in 2016 which revealed only 40% of flagged content was examined in the same time frame, and just 28% was removed, during the same period.

There's also the prospect that regulations in this space may disproportionately benefit a select few larger companies against the wider industry. The "Online Harms" white paper, for instance, will hit smaller companies with increased costs and penalties where larger companies can simply absorb these.

"The reality is that it isn't tech companies, broadly, that the government is concerned about - it's a very small number of specific big platforms," Richard Wingfield, legal officer for Global Partners Digital, told IT Pro.

"But if you look at the scope of the white paper, it's about any company or platform that allows users to share or generate content - that could be your local online newspaper that has a comments section, or Mumsnet, or blogging platforms.

"One of the unintended consequences is that you risk entrenching the dominance of the big platforms that are causing the government the most problems.

"If you impose these requirements on all of these smaller platforms, it makes them less likely to start-up in the first place - particularly if you have things like criminal liability for management of these companies."

The EU's own proposals are still being drafted, and are not expected to be published until at least the end of the year. Officials with the European Commission will engage with the tech sector about their plans, and are expected to assess the shortcomings of existing rules over the next few months.

urn:contentItem:5WN7-40G1-JCMN-Y0HD-00000-00EU plotting to overhaul rules governing tech giants2019-07-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:43:25ZLexisNexisEU plotting to overhaul rules governing tech giantsKeumarsA

Jul 24, 2019( IT Pro: http://www.itpro.co.uk Delivered by Newstex) The European Union (EU) has, for years, been incensed with the way social media firms have allowed harmful and illegal content to spread like wildfire across their networks. But officials in charge haven't quite settled on a concrete way of tackling this. Guidelines proposed by the European Commission nearly two years ago suggested a voluntary approach for tech companies[1] in removing hate speech from their platforms. However, while social media sites have been digging their heels in, the threat of enforceable regulation has been growing.In March last year, the European Commission outlined alternative plans giving these platforms just one hour to remove such content[2] before imposing penalties.

The latest proposals, according to the Financial Times[3], involve literally rewriting the rulebook on how to engage with big tech. What's being dubbed the "Digital Services Act" is expected to give the EU a raft of legal powers to influence how social media platforms govern hate speech, extremist material and political advertising.A concentration of powerThe European Commission's latest proposals go so far as to wrestle away control from individual member states and funnel this power into a continental regulator. According toNetz Politik[4], the German IT publication that originally broke the story, the new laws will substitute the older e-commerce directive, which stretches back to the year 2000. These legacy regulations are, quite simply, not fit for purpose in a modern age, and don't specify how they can be tailored to apply to the tech sector. Under these new plans, however, officials will have the opportunity to craft sharper rules to fit around all facets of modern tech like cloud computing and social media. Provisions for online political advertising[5], especially, will have a newfound prominence given how concerned the EU has been about bad actors influencing online political discourse. The most eye-catching aspect is certainly the creation of a new centralised EU tech regulator with enforcement powers. Where the EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)[6] entrusted member states with statutory powers to fine organisations for violating strict data protection principles[7], this will do the opposite. Once the Digital Services Act comes into effect, member states will be required to repeal any domestic legislation regarding blocking content, or bring this in line with the EU's, partner with White ...se LLP Tim Hickman toldIT Pro. "The boundary between EU law and the domestic laws in this area is complex. In particular, the proposed Digital Services Act aims to tackle the problem of hate speech. "However, much online speech is protected by the right to freedom of expression and information, in Article 10 of the European Convention on Human Rights, a treaty that the EU does not have the power to amend." He added domestic laws regarding freedom of expression and freedom of information fall largely outside the EU's purview. This means approaches to tackling hate speech may yet diverge from one Member State to another.The Brexit factorThe EU's moves could potentially scupper the UK's own plans to enforce regulation of online content, subject to the outcome of the Brexit fiasco and how closely the UK and EU will be regulatorily aligned. After months of dithering and speculation, the Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport (DCMS) jointly-launched proposals with the Home Office in April outlining how the government plans to tackle these very issues. If proposals outlined in the "Online Harms" white paper[8] come to fruition, the government will establish a statutory regulator with powers to punish internet giants if they neglect to abide by a "duty of care". In extreme cases, the state regulator will disrupt companies' business operations and order internet service providers (ISPs) to block non-compliant digital services or apps entirely. While the EU's plans aren't too dissimilar, under its model, proposals like these for national bodies will be overridden. One reason for this could rest with the fact a number of member states have lately elected governments of a far-right persuasion, with Hungary and Italy being notable examples. Authorities in these countries may be less likely to be decisive on the spread of some forms of hate speech and disinformation across social media networks than this proposed legislation would require. Another reason could be that countries are simply lagging behind in the process of establishing ways of monitoring and regulating harmful content online.Targeting big techThese plans are nakedly aimed at companies like Facebook and Twitter, with these platforms often rampant with "fake news" and content deemed harmful. The EU - and the UK - argue these companies have not been doing enough to get a handle on this issue. The likes of Facebook, Twitter and YouTube have, however,actually shown improvements in the way they tackle harmful content[9], with a European study published in February showing as much. For instance, during a six-week period in 2018, 89% of flagged hate speech on platforms like Facebook, YouTube and Instagram were monitored within 24 hours, with 72% of this removed. This is in contrast to a previous study published in 2016 which revealed only 40% of flagged content was examined in the same time frame, and just 28% was removed, during the same period. There's also the prospect that regulations in this space may disproportionately benefit a select few larger companies against the wider industry. The "Online Harms" white paper, for instance, will hit smaller companies with increased costs and penalties where larger companies can simply absorb these[10]. "The reality is that it isn't tech companies, broadly, that the government is concerned about - it's a very small number of specific big platforms," Richard Wingfield, legal officer for Global Partners Digital, told IT Pro. "But if you look at the scope of the white paper, it's about any company or platform that allows users to share or generate content - that could be your local online newspaper that has a comments section, or Mumsnet, or blogging platforms. "One of the unintended consequences is that you risk entrenching the dominance of the big platforms that are causing the government the most problems. "If you impose these requirements on all of these smaller platforms, it makes them less likely to start-up in the first place - particularly if you have things like criminal liability for management of these companies." The EU's own proposals are still being drafted, and are not expected to be published until at least the end of the year. Officials with the European Commission will engage with the tech sector about their plans, and are expected to assess the shortcomings of existing rules over the next few months. urn:contentItem:60G7-FRS1-F07F-81M7-00000-00EU posee más de 1 millón de documentos de investigación de las Big Tech2020-07-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:43:25ZLexisNexisNEWSEU posee más de 1 millón de documentos de investigación de las Big TechRafael Ugalde

Durante más de un año, el Gobierno Federal de Estados Unidos ha cercado a las grandes tecnológicas y sus prácticas comerciales. Este miércoles, los miembros de la Cámara de Representantes desplegarán pruebas que su personal ha encontrado y...

Durante más de un año, el Gobierno Federal de Estados Unidos ha cercado a las grandes tecnológicas y sus prácticas comerciales. Este miércoles, los miembros de la Cámara de Representantes desplegarán pruebas que su personal ha encontrado y presionarán dire...

Durante más de un año, el Gobierno Federal de Estados Unidos ha cercado a las grandes tecnológicas y sus prácticas comerciales. Este miércoles, los miembros de la Cámara de Representantes desplegarán pruebas que su personal ha encontrado y presionarán directamente a algunos de los ejecutivos más destacados del mundo. Sundar Pinchai, de Google, Alphabet; Jeff Bezos de Amazon; Tim Cook de Apple; y Mark Zuckerberg, de Facebook, están programados para responder las preguntas de los legisladores sobre sus prácticas comerciales y su enorme influencia sobre la economía y la vida cotidiana de los estadounidenses. Los directivos aparecerán a través de video y deberán esperar consultas y declaraciones fulminantes respecto a las investigaciones sobre sus prácticas comerciales por parte del Departamento de Justicia y la Comisión Federal de Comercio. Armado con 1.3 millones de documentos recolectados de las compañías y fuentes de terceros, el subcomité estará ‘enfocado en láser’ en la competencia y si la ley actual puede controlar adecuadamente su poder, dijeron los asistentes. Una línea de preguntas que mencionaron manejará las montañas de datos personales recopilados y utilizados por las compañías para construir su formidable participación en el mercado. El informe basado en el testimonio de los CEO se debe presentar a finales de este año, y a fines del verano. Bezos y sus pares corporativos están bajo el microscopio regulatorio por el considerable dominio que tienen en múltiples mercados, desde compras (a través de Amazon y Google), entretenimiento (Apple y Google,s YouTube), noticias y tutoriales instructivos (búsqueda de Google), y socialización (Facebook). El fuerte ascenso de las Big Tech, que está alimentando un mercado bursátil resurgente a pesar de una pandemia cada vez más profunda, subraya el poder duradero de la industria a medida que el consumo aumenta en una economía de trabajo desde el hogar. El ‘exceso de escrutinio regulatorio’ sigue siendo una fuente constante de ansiedad para Wall Street que espera sean objetivos en un ‘fútbol político’ entre este momento y las elecciones de noviembre, dijo el analista de Wedbush Securities Dan Ives en un comunicado.

urn:contentItem:5Y7X-7Y11-DYS1-01SD-00000-00EU possibly too late with AI proposals2020-02-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:43:25ZLexisNexisFINANCEPg. 3EU possibly too late with AI proposals

When it comes to digital innovation, Europe is usually something of a laggard. In numerous instances it has been forced to play catch-up as other regions, most notably the United States, rush ahead.

Having missed the boat multiple times, can it make up lost ground and become a leader in emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence (AI) and Big Data?

That is the certainly the hope. The European Commission on Wednesday announced a raft of new proposals aimed at ensuring it doesn't get left too far behind as Silicon Valley and China race on.

These include plans to significantly boost investment in AI and create a single European market for data. Also announced this week are proposals to rein in internet giants such as Facebook and Google.

The omens aren't good however. To many onlookers, this all looks very much like a case of closing the door after the horse has bolted.

Big tech has already achieved such immense powers that efforts to break its stronghold will be strongly resisted. Mark Zuckerberg might say he wants to see greater regulation of online platforms, but Facebook's white paper on the issue, which was published earlier this week, shows little evidence of it wanting real action to be taken.

Another problem is that just as in other instances, Europe is already way behind.

Take AI for example. Under the new plans, the European Union is seeking to attract over EUR 20 billion in investment in AI per year over the next decade, up from just EUR 3.2 billion in 2016.

However, three years ago, the US was already ploughing some EUR 12.1 billion into the technology, while Asia was investing EUR 6.5 billion. No figures are available on what the spend is now in both regions, but there is no doubt it has risen substantially.

The fact that much of the proposals announced this week are more than a little woolly will also do little to make anyone fear them.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60WD-FY41-JBN1-G2D5-00000-00EU Preparing Legislation to Strengthen Grip on Big Tech Companies - Reports2020-09-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:43:25ZLexisNexisEU Preparing Legislation to Strengthen Grip on Big Tech Companies - Reports

MOSCOW, September 20 (Sputnik) - The European Union is putting together a new legislation to challenge the market dominance of big tech companies by means of tougher regulations on content and data privacy, Financial Times reported on Sunday, citing EU Internal Market Commissioner Thierry Breton.

Tech companies will reportedly be forced to break up or sell parts of their EU-based business in the case if Brussels deems their market dominance threatening, a move strikingly similar to the United States' ultimatum to China's TikTok — get purchased by a US company or be banned in the US territory.

"We need better supervision for these big platforms," Breton said, as quoted in the report, adding "[under] certain conditions we may also have the power to impose structural separation​​​."

According to the EU official, "there is a feeling from end users of these platforms that they are too big to care."

The new legislation will reportedly give Brussels more powers to scrutinize how tech companies collect data on users as opposed to the current practice of voluntary disclosures, which, according to the report, experts say are often misleading or incomplete.

There will also be a blacklist of activities, such as banning users from switching platforms or using only one service.

At the same time, according to Breton, the EU will let the companies preserve limited liability for the content they publish on their platforms.

As outlined in the report, Europe's latest tech industry regulations, the Digital Services Act (DSA), was adopted back in 2000, when most of contemporary tech giants were either only beginning to emerge or did not exist at all. Under the new EU Commission's work program, the bloc will put forward a new DSA in the fourth quarter of 2020 as part of its goal to make Europe "fit for the digital age."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5Y7X-7Y11-DYS1-01RY-00000-00EU presents new plans for AI and data2020-02-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:43:25ZLexisNexisFINANCEPg. 1EU presents new plans for AI and dataCharlie Taylor

The European Union is seeking to attract over EUR 20 billion in investment in artificial intelligence per year over the next decade, as it looks to catch up with the United States and China.

In proposals made public yesterday, the European Commission said it also plans to create a single European market for data.

President of the European Commission Ursula von der Leyen and executive vice-president for digital affairs Margrethe Vestagerled the presentation of the AI and data initiatives in Brussels.

They form part of a a raft of digital market reforms proposed by the commission this week that also include steps to rein in the power of big tech companies such as Google, Facebook and Amazon.

Under the new proposals, there are plans to significantly boost AI investment in Europe to over EUR 20 billion. This compares to just EUR 3.2 billion in 2016.

Over the past three years, EU funding for research and innovation for AI has risen to EUR 1.5 billion, a 70 per cent increase on the prior period. However, this remains a fraction of the investment seen in North America and Asia.

The commission warned US and Chinese companies that they will have to submit to strict new rules if they want to deploy such technology in Europe. Its white paper proposes regulatory testing similar to that seen for chemicals, cosmetics and toys.

"The European Union is and will remain the most open region for trade and investment in the world, but this is not unconditional," the commission said.

'Respect our rules' "Everyone can access the European market as long as they accept and respect our rules."

A particular area of concern for the commission is facial recognition technology, although it stepped back from introducing a complete ban.

The commission said while AI can be used for good, it can also do significant harm.

"AI is a strategic technology that offers many benefits for citizens, companies and societies as a whole provided it is human-centric, ethical, sustainable and respects fundamental rights and values," the commission said in its new white paper.

One possibly controversial proposal calls for doing away with EU rules against anti-competitive data sharing. There is also a goal for data centres to be climate-neutral by 2030. - Additional reporting: Reuters/Bloomberg

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5SDC-MBR1-JCMN-Y4DB-00000-00EU privacy watchdog: Big tech firms are 'blackmailing' users into agreeing with their new data terms (FB, GOOGL)2018-05-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:43:25ZLexisNexisEU privacy watchdog: Big tech firms are 'blackmailing' users into agreeing with their new data terms (FB, GOOGL)Jake Kanter

May 25, 2018( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) European Data Protection Supervisor Europe's data watchdogis worried that big tech firms are "blackmailing" users into agreeing to new data terms introduced under General Data Protection Regulation. Giovanni Buttarelli said his office will examine tech firms' take-it-or-leave-it approach to data consent, which are already the subject of a complaint by Austrian data activist Max Schrems. Schrems claims Facebook, Google, Instagram, and WhatsApp are trying to "force you to consent" to their new privacy policies.

Buttarelli said some sentences in the policies he has seen are "arguable and controversial." Big tech companies are "blackmailing" their users into agreeing to new data terms they have introduced to comply with sweeping new European privacy laws, according to the EU's data watchdog. Giovanni Buttarelli, the European Data Protection Supervisor, told Business Insider that he has concerns about the way some firms have approached General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which came into force on Friday. He did not single out any companies, but the likes of Facebook, Google, and Twitter have all asked users to consent to new terms in recent weeks. Buttarelli said his office will examine the "tech giants'" take-it-or-leave-it approach to data consent, which he said in some cases amounts to a "blackmailing" of users because if they don't agree, they will be kicked off the platform. The consent issue is already the subject of a GDPR complaint by Austrian data activist Max Schrems[1]. On Friday, Schrems filed claims against Facebook, Google, Instagram, and WhatsApp, which he said are trying to "force you to consent" to their new privacy policies. If successful, it could result in fines of billions of dollars. "We know there are a lot of pages drafted in legalese, in a defence mode. There are some sentences that may be arguable and controversial," Buttarelli said of his early assessments of companies' updated terms, suggesting there could be some merit in Schrems' complaints.Buttarelli is responsible for helping enforce data protection laws across the EU. His office works with European member states to help them interpret regulation and protect consumers. He continued: "Is it really free and not detrimental [to take] the approach where you say: 'This is what you should accept. There is no alternative. Otherwise, you are out of the service.'" "That's a big point we have to analyse. The processing of data should be fair and not only connected to a legal base, to be freely chosen by the data controller ... "Consent was and will remain one of the requisites to process personal data, not necessarily the only one, but the main one. According to the GDPR, where indispensable, where requested, the consent should be more genuine, more transparent, more specific, more informed, more rebukable." Buttarelli said he hopes that GDPR eventually means that big tech companies take a more serious and fair approach to privacy. "Not only ticking boxes, but having a continuous and revolutionary approach to privacy. Embedding data protection into the day-to-day life of every single company. And being more accessible and transparent with the users," he explained. Facebook, which owns Instagram and WhatsApp, told Reuters that it has worked for 18 months to be compliant with GDPR[2]. Eric Schmidt, a board member at Google's parent company Alphabet, told the VivaTech conference in France on Friday: "The GDPR is the law of the land and we have fully complied with it."NOW WATCH: Steve Jobs made 3 AM phone calls to argue about Apple ads[3]See Also: Data privacy activist wastes no time in filing GDPR complaints against Facebook, Google, Instagram, and WhatsApp[4]Mark Zuckerberg said the 'vast majority' of people actively opt into one of Facebook's most invasive features[5]What you need to know about GDPR, the new EU privacy rules that have Silicon Valley scrambling to keep up[6] SEE ALSO:Data privacy activist wastes no time in filing GDPR complaints against Facebook, Google, Instagram, and WhatsApp[7] [ 1]: http://www.businessinsider.com/max-screms-gdpr-complaints-facebook-google-2018-5?utm_source=partner..._medium=newstex..._term=original..._campaign=partner [ 2]:   http://www.businessinsider.com/max-screms-gdpr-complaints-facebook-google-2018-5?utm_source=partner..._medium=newstex..._term=original..._campaign=partner [ 3]:   http://www.businessinsider.com/errol-morris-steve-jobs-making-of-apple-switch-ad-campaign-2018-5?utm_source=partner..._medium=newstex..._term=original..._campaign=partner [ 4]:   http://www.businessinsider.com/max-screms-gdpr-complaints-facebook-google-2018-5?utm_source=partner..._medium=newstex..._term=original..._campaign=partner [ 5]:   http://www.businessinsider.com/mark-zuckerberg-gdpr-privacy-changes-not-problem-for-users-2018-5?utm_source=partner..._medium=newstex..._term=original..._campaign=partner [ 6]:   http://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-gdpr-regulation-explained-2018-4?utm_source=partner..._medium=newstex..._term=original..._campaign=partner [ 7]:   http://www.businessinsider.com/max-screms-gdpr-complaints-facebook-google-2018-5?utm_source=partner..._medium=newstex..._term=original..._campaign=partner

Apple’s Siri, Amazon’s Alexa and other voice-activated assistants are on the hot seat as one of the world’s largest regulatory bodies takes aim at the Internet of Things (IoT). The European Commission (EC) said Thursday (July 16) it has launched a “sector ... Apple’s Siri,...

Apple’s Siri, Amazon’s Alexa and other voice-activated assistants are on the hot seat as one of the world’s largest regulatory bodies takes aim at the Internet of Things (IoT). The European Commission (EC) said Thursday (July 16) it has launched a “sector ...

Apple’s Siri, Amazon’s Alexa and other voice-activated assistants are on the hot seat as one of the world’s largest regulatory bodies takes aim at the Internet of Things (IoT). The European Commission (EC) said Thursday (July 16) it has launched a “sector inquiry” into the Internet of Things, citing concerns that a few big tech giants could use data collected by voice assistants to box out competitors and build up monopoly power over the emerging field. Nor is it just Sire and Alexa on the hotseat, with the EU, in a press release announcing the inquiry, also citing Google Assistant and Magenta, Deutsche Telekom’s friendly voice-activated assistant. “Voice assistants and smart devices can collect a vast amount of data about our habits,” Margrethe Vestager, executive vice president at the EC, said in the press statement. “And there’s a risk that big companies could misuse the data collected through such devices, to cement their position in the market against the challenges of competition. They might even use their knowledge of how we access other services to enter the market for those services and take it over.” In a first step, the EC said it will be sending out questionnaires to 400 companies, not just in Europe, but across Asia and the Americas as well, about how companies collect data and how they make money from the data they collect. The inquiries are being targeted at companies that sell “smart home appliances, wearables and voice assistants,” as well as businesses that offer services that are accesses through these smart devices. The aim is to both help the commission “spot situations where companies may have broken the competition rules” as well as add to level of knowledge among EU regulators about the emerging sector, Vestager said. The number of smart home devices in Europe is expected to hit 184 million in 2023, up from 108 million at the end of 2019, the commission noted. —————————— New PYMNTS Study: Subscription Commerce Conversion Index – July 2020 Staying home 24/7 has consumers turning to subscription services for both entertainment and their day-to-day needs. While that’s a great opportunity for providers, it also presents a challenge — 27.4 million consumers are looking to cancel their subscriptions because of friction and cost concerns. In the latest Subscription Commerce Conversion Index , PYMNTS reveals the five key features that can help companies keep subscribers loyal despite today’s challenging economic times. value.Title: EU Probe Into IoT Targets Siri, Alexa Over Data Collection
value.Overview: Apple’s Siri, Amazon’s Alexa and other voice-activated assistants are on the hot seat as one of the world’s largest regulatory bodies takes aim at the Internet of Things (IoT). The European Commission (EC) said Thursday (July 16) it has launched a “sector ... Apple’s Siri,...

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60CH-V231-F07F-81VD-00000-00EU Probe Into IoT Targets Siri, Alexa Over Data Collection2020-07-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:43:25ZLexisNexisNEWSEU Probe Into IoT Targets Siri, Alexa Over Data Collection

Apple’s Siri, Amazon’s Alexa and other voice-activated assistants are on the hot seat as one of the world’s largest regulatory bodies takes aim at the Internet of Things (IoT). The European Commission (EC) said Thursday (July 16) it has launched a “sector ... Apple’s Siri,...

Apple’s Siri, Amazon’s Alexa and other voice-activated assistants are on the hot seat as one of the world’s largest regulatory bodies takes aim at the Internet of Things (IoT). The European Commission (EC) said Thursday (July 16) it has launched a “sector ...

Apple’s Siri, Amazon’s Alexa and other voice-activated assistants are on the hot seat as one of the world’s largest regulatory bodies takes aim at the Internet of Things (IoT). The European Commission (EC) said Thursday (July 16) it has launched a “sector inquiry” into the Internet of Things, citing concerns that a few big tech giants could use data collected by voice assistants to box out competitors and build up monopoly power over the emerging field. Nor is it just Siri and Alexa on the hotseat, with the EU, in a press release announcing the inquiry, also citing Google Assistant and Magenta, Deutsche Telekom’s friendly voice-activated assistant. “Voice assistants and smart devices can collect a vast amount of data about our habits,” Margrethe Vestager, executive vice president at the EC, said in the press statement. “And there’s a risk that big companies could misuse the data collected through such devices, to cement their position in the market against the challenges of competition. They might even use their knowledge of how we access other services to enter the market for those services and take it over.” In a first step, the EC said it will be sending out questionnaires to 400 companies, not just in Europe, but across Asia and the Americas as well, about how companies collect data and how they make money from the data they collect. The inquiries are being targeted at companies that sell “smart home appliances, wearables and voice assistants,” as well as businesses that offer services that are accesses through these smart devices. The aim is to both help the commission “spot situations where companies may have broken the competition rules” as well as add to level of knowledge among EU regulators about the emerging sector, Vestager said. The number of smart home devices in Europe is expected to hit 184 million in 2023, up from 108 million at the end of 2019, the commission noted. —————————— New PYMNTS Study: Subscription Commerce Conversion Index – July 2020 Staying home 24/7 has consumers turning to subscription services for both entertainment and their day-to-day needs. While that’s a great opportunity for providers, it also presents a challenge — 27.4 million consumers are looking to cancel their subscriptions because of friction and cost concerns. In the latest Subscription Commerce Conversion Index , PYMNTS reveals the five key features that can help companies keep subscribers loyal despite today’s challenging economic times. Recommended for you

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VVY-RPN1-JCBB-K16V-00000-00EU Probes Amazon As Politicians Hammer Big Tech, But 2 FANGs Are In Buy Zones2019-07-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:43:25ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYEU Probes Amazon As Politicians Hammer Big Tech, But 2 FANGs Are In Buy ZonesJED GRAHAM

https://www.investors.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/A1MAIN-bigtech-041219.jpg

Major antitrust action keeps edging closer to Big Tech. Will it ever reach them? It's still not certain, but the European Union just took a pretty big step. The European Commission on Wednesday announced a formal antitrust probe into Amazon and its use of "competitively sensitive information." The news comes just after the U.S. House antitrust panel hauled executives from Amazon, Facebook and Google-parent Alphabet and Apple before it. On June 3, Google stock, Amazon stock, Facebook stock and Apple stock all slid on news that the Justice Department and Federal Trade Commission had divvied up responsibility over the companies. That was seen as preliminary step ahead of the possible antitrust probes.

FANG Stocks Shake Off Antitrust Fears

New political threats to the business models that Amazon, Facebook and Google parent Alphabet rode to stunning success seem to pop up each week. A growing web of investigation, regulation and legislation threatens to tie down or break up these big technology companies. Meanwhile, Apple has come under scrutiny for its App Store rules.

Still, investors don't seem overly nervous about the risks to Amazon stock, Google stock, Facebook stock, and Apple stock. After falling pretty sharply on June 3 at the prospect of federal antitrust probes, the FANG stocks have rallied. Amazon stock cleared a buy point on July 9 and remained in a buy zone after dipping 0.9% Wednesday on news of the EU probe.

Facebook stock also cleared a buy point on July 9 and remains in buy range, about 8% off its all-time high. Google stock. As of July 17, Google stock is up about 12% since June 3, but still about 11% below its record high. Apple stock is up 18% since June 3 and is within 5% of a buy zone.

Growing Threat To Big Tech

While the most dire threats still look distant for tech stocks Amazon, Facebook and Google parent Alphabet, investors must take political risk seriously now because markets can suddenly reach a tipping point and factor in long-term threats.

"Big Tech is becoming too big to control" in the eyes of government, RBC Capital Markets analyst Mark Mahaney told IBD.

Already, that's likely quashed another big acquisition by these giant tech companies, Mahaney says. Online privacy regulation will probably "somewhat" reduce their ability to do targeted advertising, he says.

While the Big Tech stocks' ultimate exposure to regulation is unclear, the trajectory is a concern. "The possibility that something could affect their business models — that continues to rise," Mahaney said.

The Justice Department will investigate Google and will have lead oversight on Apple. The FTC took over Amazon and Facebook antitrust issues. House Democrats also have launched a broad antitrust investigation of big technology companies.

Facebook has faced a drumbeat of calls for its breakup, including from a co-founder. NBC reported recently on 4,000 pages of leaked documents covering the period from 2011 to 2015. NBC summed its findings up this way: "In some cases, Facebook would reward favored companies by giving them access to the data of its users. In other cases, it would deny user-data access to rival companies or apps."

Bipartisan Appeal Of Regulating Big Technology Companies

Efforts to have been building for years. But the path to game-changing regulation vs. big technology companies suddenly is much more plausible. The FANGs no longer have fierce protectors in Washington. The left now sees them as symbols of inequality, not cultural soul mates. At the moment, the right cares more about censorship and perceived anti-conservative bias than capital gains.

Democratic presidential hopeful to break up the big internet companies Facebook, Google and Amazon made few waves. Yet Warren has a couple of potential allies with big bullhorns. Rupert Murdoch, who controls Fox News, recently asked an Australia competition panel to break up Google. President Trump last year called Google, Facebook and Amazon "a very antitrust situation."

The Federal Trade Commission earlier this year announced a task force to scrutinize mergers it had previously rubber-stamped. Those include Facebook's Instagram deal and Google's DoubleClick buy.

Why Break Up Facebook, Google Or Amazon?

This trio of giant internet companies have become so indispensable that greater regulation and even antitrust scrutiny have become inevitable.

Amazon, with 100 million Prime members in the U.S., handles close to half of online sales, as e-commerce steadily encroaches on traditional retail. Google processes 90% or more of all search requests, while its Android is the dominant mobile operating system. More than 2 billion people network globally via Facebook each month. Together, Google and Facebook control 60% of U.S. digital ad spending, and more than half of ad spending has moved online. Amazon is becoming a big online ad player too.

Their dominant digital platforms give these massive technology companies the financial clout and user data to buy up or stamp out competitive threats, critics say. On top of that, Google and Amazon face accusations of tilting supposedly level playing fields in their own favor. Google and Facebook users have little choice but to put up with invasive privacy terms.

While opinions diverge over Amazon's e-commerce dominance, both parties seem to see the online ad duopoly of Google and Facebook as too powerful.

The grilling of Google senior privacy counsel Will DeVries at a March 12 Senate hearing underscored the risk they face. "Do you think that an average consumer who's using your products fully understands that Google builds a profile about her, tracks where she goes to work, tracks where her boyfriend lives, tracks where she goes to church, tracks when she goes to the doctor?" Republican Sen. Josh Hawley of Missouri demanded. "Americans have not signed up for this," but they can't easily opt out, he railed.

Political Risk For Facebook Stock, Alphabet Stock, Amazon Stock

The current debate in Congress over online privacy rules is one possible trigger for Wall Street reassessing longer-term risks to Facebook stock, Alphabet stock and even Amazon stock.

Hawley wants a ban of tracking kids online, unless parents opt in. Sen. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., wants a Do Not Track registry. That would let people simply opt out of companies sharing and selling their data to target ads.

Such online privacy regulations could become headwinds to growth. Yet that might be a modest price — if digital privacy rules relieve the sense of urgency for harsher action against big technology companies.

Facebook, Google and Amazon have become the modern equivalent of great white whales — whose power and elusiveness have inspired legions in pursuit. Now national figures in both political parties, along with numerous state attorneys general, have joined the quest.

International regulators have led the way in going after America's homegrown internet success stories and are still hot on the trail.

The with three multibillion-dollar fines in the past two years. Regulators penalized Google for discriminating against online ad rivals, favoring Google Shopping in search results, and requiring Google Chrome's inclusion on new Android phones.

The EU's new copyright directive will require Google to sign licensing agreements with news publishers, musicians and other artists to use their work or post snippets of news articles. Facebook and Instagram will have to filter out copyrighted material.

On July 17, Margrethe Vestager, EU competition commissioner, said that a preliminary probe found that "Amazon appears to use competitively sensitive information — about marketplace sellers, their products and transactions on the marketplace." Next, she'll look at whether Amazon's practices breach EU competition rules.

Sorting The Threats To Facebook, Google And Amazon

While all of the threats to these big technology companies matter, investors can lump them into three general categories.

The sharks: These money grabs or financial penalties might inflict painful flesh wounds but don't pose fundamental risk. A $5 billion FTC fine to punish Facebook for exposing 87 million users' data to Cambridge Analytica falls into that category. France's revenue grab aimed at the internet giants with a 3% tax on their online sales offers another example.

Harpooning the giant technology companies: Antitrust action to break up big technology companies gets the most ink and sounds the most damaging.

The more plausible risk may be a web of regulation that ensnares the massive internet companies and saps their dynamism, like whales trapped in a bay.

The last Big Tech breakup was AT&T in 1982. Antitrust action vs. internet giants would involve a long drawn-out court battle. Odds of success before the conservative-leaning Supreme Court don't look great. U.S. antitrust law stresses consumer welfare.

Proving that Big Tech domination has hurt consumers is no easy task. Facebook and Google services are free while Amazon has helped keep inflation low.

Facebook Stock In Breakup Scenario

A breakup might not be that damaging for Facebook stock, argues Rosenblatt Securities analyst Mark Zgutowicz. "We see potential -13% downside to FB shares if the company is forced to spin out Instagram," he wrote after the FTC launched its review of old technology mergers.

That would reflect the added costs of running two companies. But Zgutowicz sees a Facebook breakup as unlikely. Because Instagram skews to a younger audience than Facebook, a breakup might not unlock much competition, he says.

Needham & Co. analyst Laura Martin told IBD that it would behoove Facebook, Amazon and Google "to break themselves up."

"I don't think the fear of size is going to dissipate," she said. And Wall Street would welcome more transparency and the chance to invest in pure-play tech stocks like a stand-alone YouTube and Amazon Web Services.

Yet a breakup would be a strategic blow to Facebook. In early March, Facebook said it would move ahead integrating its Messenger, WhatsApp, and Instagram properties. That would let users of one site communicate privately with those on all Facebook platforms. It also would make a Facebook breakup more technically complex.

Facebook Integration Tests Regulators

Facebook's integration, made official just as the FTC said it will review whether Facebook's past deals were anti-competitive, was a daring stroke — like swimming straight toward a fleet of whaling ships.

Meanwhile, Germany's antitrust regulator said in February that Facebook must get permission from users to combine their data across its three platforms. The top regulator likened the move to an "internal" breakup, without actually splitting Facebook into parts. Facebook is appealing the order.

Facebook aims to be the go-to communication and payments platform for its billions of users. It wants to play the same role as Tencent messaging app WeChat in China. That vision goes hand in hand with Facebook plans to launch its own cryptocurrency.

"But there's a key difference between Facebook Inc. and WeChat: government oversight," wrote Forrester senior analyst Jessica Liu. She sees Facebook as "trying to strike an impossible balance." It aims to sop up more of users' time and more ad dollars, while appeasing privacy and antitrust regulators.

Facebook's 'Dangerous Power Grab'

Facebook's integration drive might backfire — if it leads regulators to act with greater urgency.

House antitrust panel chair David Cicilline, D-R.I., called Facebook's integration "a dangerous power grab to head off antitrust action." Since then, the FTC said it's demanding nonpublic data as it scrutinizes the big online platforms.

Not surprisingly, Facebook has encountered broad resistance — from the Fed, the Treasury Dept. and Congress — to its plan to launch a Libra cryptocurrency.

Yet, Facebook also may have dodged a bullet. The over Facebook letting Cambridge Analytica, a Trump campaign contractor, access personal data to target 2016 election messaging. Facebook escaped without having to consent to major operational changes.

Backlash Against Facebook, Google Tracking, Big Data

Privacy regulation is among the biggest risks to Facebook and Google stock. That would target the technology companies' cash cow: revenue from targeted advertising based on a consumer's interests, demographics, search activity, location, travel habits, relationships and more.

Late last year, research firm Gartner predicted a "global backlash" against such tracking of personal information, "crippling the current internet ad revenue machine" by 2023.

Studies have estimated that a draft eprivacy regulation in the European Union could cut European display ad revenue by 50% to 70%. The draft rules would enable consumers to manage privacy settings via their browser.

That might empower people overwhelmed by the current system of setting privacy preferences on a site-by-site basis. Yet it's far from clear that the EU will adopt that approach.

Regulators in the U.S. and abroad will likely try to strike a balance between privacy and fostering ad-based business models. California's online privacy bill passed last year requires websites to have a conspicuous "Do Not Sell My Personal Information" button.

Google and Facebook influenced that California law, hastily passed to derail a potentially far more damaging ballot initiative. Now the big internet companies hope to steer a more forgiving federal digital privacy bill to pre-empt state measures. California's law is set to take effect in 2020.

Regulating The Amazon Marketplace Platform

For Amazon, regulation risk centers on its dual role operating the dominant e-commerce marketplace while also being its fiercest competitor.

Dominant platform operators shouldn't be "both the judge and the jury," argues a new report on digital competition for the European Commission.

Beyond reversing mergers with Whole Foods and Zappos, Warren called for designating Amazon a "platform utility." She says "companies would be prohibited from owning both the platform utility and any participants on that platform."

In its severest form, regulating Amazon as a platform would look like what's been happening in India. To comply with India's new rule to keep foreign companies from dominating its retail market, Amazon and Flipkart, majority-owned by Walmart, began the year pulling hundreds of thousands of items from their websites.

AmazonBasics merchandise were among the sidelined products. Further, Amazon must sell off 49% stakes in Cloudtail India and Appario Retail. They were big sellers on Amazon but face a much less certain future as independent entities. Bottom line:  sales in India are seen taking a $5 billion, or 40%, hit.

Amazon seems to recognize the risk. Earlier this year, it took two steps to quiet criticism. First, it stopped demanding that sellers on its platform match their lowest price offered on any third-party site. Then it toned down aggressive marketing on its site for its in-house AmazonBasics.

Leveling The Playing Field With Amazon, Google, Facebook

Critics say the trio of FANG stocks use their Big Data advantage to identify and nip potential rivals in the bud. But high hurdles to litigating and winning an antitrust case have led to under-enforcement of discrimination in online markets.

It's one thing to say that Amazon shouldn't be judge and jury, and another to say it can't be a seller on its own platform.

There may be a middle ground. When cable operators ran the dominant platform, the FCC created a tribunal to handle complaints they gave preference to their own programming.

Economist Hal Singer has proposed a similar tribunal to judge complaints of unfair competition brought against Amazon and today's other big digital platforms. The idea seems to be gaining steam.

Technology Regulation More Than Just FANGs

Reining in big technology companies isn't just an issue for Alphabet stock, Facebook stock and Amazon stock. The broad tech universe, including Apple and Microsoft, is at risk.

The Supreme Court recently allowed a suit to continue vs. the Apple App Store.

Democratic presidential hopefuls Amy Klobuchar, Cory Booker and Kirsten Gillibrand want to raise the bar for big technology company mergers. Their bill would establish a presumption that acquisitions by companies with at least a $100 billion market cap are anti-competitive. That would apply to about two dozen S&P 500 companies.

Yet such efforts to stimulate more competition could create a chill from the venture capital world on up. Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Microsoft have made 431 acquisitions worth $155.7 billion over the past decade, Bloomberg data show. Technology investors could lose their pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.

An earlier version of this article originally ran as the cover story in the print edition for the week of April 15.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WKH-G6K1-JDR2-00M3-00000-00EU PROBING AMAZON OVER USE OF RETAILERS' DATA TO GAIN EDGE2019-07-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:43:25ZLexisNexisDATAEU PROBING AMAZON OVER USE OF RETAILERS' DATA TO GAIN EDGE

The European Union is opening a new front in its quest to regulate big tech companies, investigating whether Amazon uses data from independent retailers to gain an illegal edge when selling its own products.

EU antitrust commissioner Margrethe Vestager said she is taking a "very close look at Amazon's business practices and its dual role as marketplace and retailer, to assess its compliance with EU competition rules".

In addition to selling its own products, the US online giant also allows third-party retailers to sell their goods through its site. Last year, more than half of the items sold on Amazon worldwide were from third-party sellers.

The EU opened a preliminary probe into the issue last year, and Ms Vestager said it has shown that Amazon "appears to use competitively sensitive information - about marketplace sellers, their products and transactions on the marketplace". Using the information could give it an unfair competitive edge.

In a parallel case, Germany's competition regulator said Amazon was changing some of its business conditions for traders on its online marketplace worldwide after it raised concerns about some terms.

The regulator said the changes affect a range of issues such as a one-sided exemption from liability to Amazon's benefit as well as the place of jurisdiction for disputes.

Other EU countries like Austria , Luxembourg and Italy are also independently investigating Amazon but EU spokeswoman Lucia Caudet said the national probes did not overlap with the EU investigation.

Amazon said it would co-operate with the EU authorities, according to media reports.

The EU's investigations into major companies like Amazon have led the way in a global push to more tightly regulate tech giants, as many governments wonder if they are becoming too big for the good of the wider economy.

Among the key questions are not only whether the tech giants abuse their market dominance to choke off competition, potentially stifling choice for consumers, but also whether they are adequately protecting users data and paying their fair share of taxes in countries where they operate.

Tech companies do huge business across Europe but pay taxes only in the EU nation where their local headquarters are based, often a low-tax haven like Luxembourg or the Netherlands . The result is they pay a far lower rate than traditional businesses.

France has tried to address the problem by unilaterally imposing a 3% tax on big tech companies' revenue in the country. The US government is not happy about that and finance ministers from the G7 wealthy countries will discuss the issue this week in Paris .

Ursula von der Leyen , the EU Commission president elect who should take up her role in November, has said she will try to be more vigilant to make sure such companies pay enough taxes.

Amazon has already been the target of previous EU investigations. Two years ago, officials ordered it to pay 295 million dollars in back taxes to Luxembourg after finding that the company profited from a tax avoidance deal with the tiny European country.

EU officials also investigated Amazon's e-book business.

urn:contentItem:5Y4T-P081-F03R-N1BS-00000-00EU proposes data-centric single market to challenge US tech giants2020-02-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:43:25ZLexisNexisEU proposes data-centric single market to challenge US tech giants

Jan 30, 2020( IT Pro: http://www.itpro.co.uk Delivered by Newstex) The European Union[1] wants to create a data-centric single market in order to challenge the dominance of US companiessuch as Google, Facebook, and Amazon.In a proposal document drafted by the European Commission, the EU wants to make it easier for companies within its borders to have more scope to tap into the bloc's large quantities fo industrial and professional data, Reuters[2]has reported.While the collection and use of personal data are heavily regulated in the EU[3] due to its General DataProtection Regulation (GDPR)[4], the proposal document wants to provide free access for European tech companies to use more corporate and public data, such as environmental and geospatial, and statistical information.With access to such information, the EC envisions #8216;a single European data space, a genuine single market[5] for data#8217;.Advertisement - Article continues below#8216;Competitors such as China and the US are already innovating quickly and projecting their concepts of data access and use across the globe,#8217; the document said. Related Resource Your guide to overcoming Brexit's data management challengesUnderstand Brexit andthedata law modificationsit may cause Download now[6] #8216;Currently a small number of big tech firms hold a large part of the world's data. This is a major weakness for data-driven businesses to emerge, grow and innovate today, including in Europe, but huge opportunities lie ahead.#8217;To that end, the proposal outlines the need for new rules to cover cross-border data use, new industry standards in areas such as financial services, agriculture, healthcare, and manufacturing, and data interoperability in order to facilitate better data-sharing across the bloc's nation-states.Furthermore, the document proposes the removal of existing competition rules that hinder data sharing, while also introducing policies that prevent large online services and platforms from imposing conditions on data use and access which give them disproportionate benefits.The overall goal is to keep the data market #8216;open and fair#8217;, effectively rallying against the power of data-centric tech giants that arguably have a stranglehold over the data market.The proposal is due to be presented on 19 February, which leaves space for the document to be tweaked and amended.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5Y86-46V1-F12B-J4B2-00000-00EU proposes new AI rules to limit risks2020-02-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:43:25ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. A024EU proposes new AI rules to limit risks

The European Union has unveiled proposals to regulate artificial intelligence that call for strict rules and safeguards on risky applications of the rapidly developing technology.

The report is part of the bloc's wider digital strategy aimed at maintaining its position as the global pacesetter on technological standards.

Big tech companies seeking to tap Europe's vast and lucrative market, including those from the US and China, would have to play by any new rules that come into force.

The EU's executive Commission said it wants to develop a "framework for trustworthy artificial intelligence". European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen had ordered her top deputies to come up with a coordinated European approach to artificial intelligence and data strategy 100 days after she took office in December.

"We will be particularly careful where essential human rights and interests are at stake," von der Leyen told reporters in Brussels. "Artificial intelligence must serve people, and therefore artificial intelligence must always comply with people's rights."

EU leaders, keen on establishing "technological sovereignty", also released a strategy to unlock data from the continent's businesses and the public sector so it can be harnessed for further innovation in artificial intelligence.

They also warned that even more regulation for foreign tech companies is in store with the upcoming "Digital Services Act", a sweeping overhaul of how the bloc treats digital companies, including potentially holding them liable for illegal content posted on their platforms.

Under the proposals EU authorities want to be able to test and certify the data used by the algorithms that power artificial intelligence in the same way they check cosmetics, cars and toys.

It's important to use unbiased data to train high-risk artificial intelligence systems so they can avoid discrimination, the commission said.

Other ideas include preserving data to help trace any problems and having AI systems clearly spell out their capabilities and limitations.

Users should be told when they're interacting with a machine and not a human while humans should be in charge of the system and have the final say on decisions such as rejecting an application for welfare benefits, the report said.

EU leaders said they also wanted to open a debate on when to allow facial recognition in remote identification systems, which are used to scan crowds to check people's faces to those on a database. AP

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60X6-GYV1-F19Y-C205-00000-00EU proposes new powers to regulate big tech companies FT2020-09-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:43:25ZLexisNexisEU proposes new powers to regulate big tech companies FTFrances Josephine Espeso

The European Union's proposed new powers include the ability to compel big tech companies to break up or divest some of their European businesses, Internal Market Commissioner Thierry Breton told the Financial Times (London).

The European Union is seeking new powers for the regulation of large tech companies, the Financial Times (London) reported Sept. 20, citing Internal Market Commissioner Thierry Breton.

The proposed powers include the ability to compel large tech companies to break up or divest some of their European businesses if authorities view their market dominance as a threat to customers' or smaller rivals' interests.

Breton told the Financial Times that the proposed powers also include the ability to completely exclude big tech companies from the single market, according to the report.

The European Commission is reportedly mulling a rating system in which stakeholders and the public can evaluate companies' behavior in areas including tax compliance and promptness of removing illegal content, among other fields.

Breton said draft legislation will be ready by the end of 2020.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5RXR-95F1-JBSJ-918W-00000-00EU Proposes Online Turnover Tax For Big Tech Firms2018-03-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:43:25ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSEU Proposes Online Turnover Tax For Big Tech Firms

Reuters (3/21, Blenkinsop) reports the European Commission on Wednesday proposed rules to "make digital companies pay more tax, with US tech giants such as Google, Facebook and Amazon set to foot a large chunk of any bill." Under the Commission's plan, companies with "significant digital revenues in Europe will pay a 3 percent tax on their turnover on various online services in the European Union, bringing in an estimated 5 billion euros." The Washington Post (3/21, Birnbaum, 15.96M) says the move "comes amid a rapidly-heating trade conflict between Europe and the United States," but is "likely to run into skepticism from the countries that serve as the legal homes to the companies, as well as small tech-savvy nations such as Estonia, where the technology behind Skype was born." The New York Times (3/21, Schreuer, Subscription Publication, 13.35M) says the proposals "support the argument that Europe is the world's most prominent regulator of technology and digital services."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5Y7Y-R831-DY37-F1V5-00000-00EU proposes regulations to limit the risks from AICommission says clear rules needed to address systems2020-02-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:43:25ZLexisNexisA SECTIONAPg. 16EU proposes regulations to limit the risks from AI
Commission says clear rules needed to address systemsKelvin ChanAssociated Press

LONDON - The European Union unveiled proposals Wednesday to regulate artificial intelligence that call for strict rules and safeguards on risky applications of the rapidly developing technology.

The report is part of the bloc's wider digital strategy aimed at maintaining its position as the global pacesetter on technological standards. Big tech companies seeking to tap Europe's vast and lucrative market, including those from the U.S. and China, would have to play by any new rules that come into force.

The EU's executive Commission said it wants to develop a "framework for trustworthy artificial intelligence." European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen had ordered her top deputies to come up with a coordinated European approach to artificial intelligence and data strategy 100 days after she took office in December.

"We will be particularly careful where essential human rights and interests are at stake," von der Leyen told reporters in Brussels. "Artificial intelligence must serve people, and therefore artificial intelligence must always comply with people's rights."

EU leaders, keen on establishing "technological sovereignty," also released a strategy to unlock data from the continent's businesses and the public sector so it can be harnessed for further innovation in artificial intelligence. Officials in Europe, which doesn't have any homegrown tech giants, hope to catch up with the U.S. and China by using the bloc's vast and growing trove of industrial data for what they anticipate is a coming wave of digital transformation.

They also warned that even more regulation for foreign tech companies is in store with the upcoming "Digital Services Act," a sweeping overhaul of how the bloc treats digital companies, including potentially holding them liable for illegal content posted on their platforms. A steady stream of Silicon Valley tech bosses, including Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg, Google CEO Sundar Pichai and Microsoft President Brad Smith, have visited Brussels in recent weeks as part of apparent lobbying efforts.

"It is not us that need to adapt to today's platforms. It is the platforms that need to adapt to Europe," said Thierry Breton, commissioner for the internal market. "That is the message that we delivered to CEOs of these platforms when they come to see us."

If the tech companies aren't able to build systems "for our people, then we will regulate, and we are ready to do this in the Digital Services Act at the end of the year," he said.

The EU's report said clear rules are needed to address "high-risk AI systems," such as those in recruitment, healthcare, law enforcement or transport, which should be "transparent, traceable and guarantee human oversight." Other artificial intelligence systems could come with labels certifying that they are in line with EU standards.

It's important to use unbiased data to train high-risk artificial intelligence systems so they can avoid discrimination, the commission said.

urn:contentItem:5Y7Y-R831-DY37-F1Y3-00000-00EU proposes regulations to limit the risks from AICommission says clear rules needed to address systems2020-02-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:43:25ZLexisNexisBUSINESSAPg. 7EU proposes regulations to limit the risks from AI
Commission says clear rules needed to address systemsKelvin ChanAssociated Press

LONDON - The European Union unveiled proposals Wednesday to regulate artificial intelligence that call for strict rules and safeguards on risky applications of the rapidly developing technology.

The report is part of the bloc's wider digital strategy aimed at maintaining its position as the global pacesetter on technological standards. Big tech companies seeking to tap Europe's vast and lucrative market, including those from the U.S. and China, would have to play by any new rules that come into force.

The EU's executive Commission said it wants to develop a "framework for trustworthy artificial intelligence." European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen had ordered her top deputies to come up with a coordinated European approach to artificial intelligence and data strategy 100 days after she took office in December.

"We will be particularly careful where essential human rights and interests are at stake," von der Leyen told reporters in Brussels. "Artificial intelligence must serve people, and therefore artificial intelligence must always comply with people's rights."

EU leaders, keen on establishing "technological sovereignty," also released a strategy to unlock data from the continent's businesses and the public sector so it can be harnessed for further innovation in artificial intelligence. Officials in Europe, which doesn't have any homegrown tech giants, hope to catch up with the U.S. and China by using the bloc's vast and growing trove of industrial data for what they anticipate is a coming wave of digital transformation.

They also warned that even more regulation for foreign tech companies is in store with the upcoming "Digital Services Act," a sweeping overhaul of how the bloc treats digital companies, including potentially holding them liable for illegal content posted on their platforms. A steady stream of Silicon Valley tech bosses, including Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg, Google CEO Sundar Pichai and Microsoft President Brad Smith, have visited Brussels in recent weeks as part of apparent lobbying efforts.

"It is not us that need to adapt to today's platforms. It is the platforms that need to adapt to Europe," said Thierry Breton, commissioner for the internal market. "That is the message that we delivered to CEOs of these platforms when they come to see us."

If the tech companies aren't able to build systems "for our people, then we will regulate, and we are ready to do this in the Digital Services Act at the end of the year," he said.

The EU's report said clear rules are needed to address "high-risk AI systems," such as those in recruitment, healthcare, law enforcement or transport, which should be "transparent, traceable and guarantee human oversight." Other artificial intelligence systems could come with labels certifying that they are in line with EU standards.

It's important to use unbiased data to train high-risk artificial intelligence systems so they can avoid discrimination, the commission said.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5Y7X-DF31-JC65-52BX-00000-00EU proposes rules for artificial intelligence to limit risks2020-02-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:43:25ZLexisNexisBUSINESS NEWSEU proposes rules for artificial intelligence to limit risksBy KELVIN CHANAP Business WriterLONDON

LONDON (AP) - The European Union unveiled proposals Wednesday to regulate artificial intelligence that call for strict rules and safeguards on risky applications of the rapidly developing technology.

The report is part of the bloc's wider digital strategy aimed at maintaining its position as the global pacesetter on technological standards. Big tech companies seeking to tap Europe's vast and lucrative market, including those from the U.S. and China, would have to play by any new rules that come into force.

The EU's executive Commission said it wants to develop a "framework for trustworthy artificial intelligence." European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen had ordered her top deputies to come up with a coordinated European approach to artificial intelligence and data strategy 100 days after she took office in December.

"We will be particularly careful where essential human rights and interests are at stake," von der Leyen told reporters in Brussels. "Artificial intelligence must serve people, and therefore artificial intelligence must always comply with people's rights."

EU leaders, keen on establishing "technological sovereignty," also released a strategy to unlock data from the continent's businesses and the public sector so it can be harnessed for further innovation in artificial intelligence. Officials in Europe, which doesn't have any homegrown tech giants, hope to to catch up with the U.S. and China by using the bloc's vast and growing trove of industrial data for what they anticipate is a coming wave of digital transformation.

They also warned that even more regulation for foreign tech companies is in store with the upcoming "Digital Services Act," a sweeping overhaul of how the bloc treats digital companies, including potentially holding them liable for illegal content posted on their platforms. A steady stream of Silicon Valley tech bosses, including Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg, Google CEO Sundar Pichai and Microsoft President Brad Smith, have visited Brussels in recent weeks as part of apparent lobbying efforts.

"It is not us that need to adapt to today's platforms. It is the platforms that need to adapt to Europe," said Thierry Breton, commissioner for the internal market. "That is the message that we delivered to CEOs of these platforms when they come to see us."

If the tech companies aren't able to build systems "for our people, then we will regulate, and we are ready to do this in the Digital Services Act at the end of the year," he said.

The EU's report said clear rules are needed to address "high-risk AI systems," such as those in recruitment, healthcare, law enforcement or transport, which should be "transparent, traceable and guarantee human oversight." Other artificial intelligence systems could come with labels certifying that they are in line with EU standards.

Artificial intelligence uses computers to process large sets of data and make decisions without human input. It is used, for example, to trade stocks in financial markets, or, in some countries, to scan faces in crowds to find criminal suspects.

While it can be used to improve healthcare, make farming more efficient or combat climate change, it also brings risks. It can be unclear what data artificial intelligence systems work off. Facial recognition systems can be biased against certain social groups, for example. There are also concerns about privacy and the use of the technology for criminal purposes, the report said.

Human-centered guidelines for artificial intelligence are essential because "none of the positive things will be achieved if we distrust the technology," said Margrethe Vestager, the executive vice president overseeing the EU's digital strategy.

Under the proposals, which are open for public consultation until May 19, EU authorities want to be able to test and certify the data used by the algorithms that power artificial intelligence in the same way they check cosmetics, cars and toys.

It's important to use unbiased data to train high-risk artificial intelligence systems so they can avoid discrimination, the commission said.

Specifically, AI systems could be required to use data reflecting gender, ethnicity and "other possible grounds of prohibited discrimination."

Other ideas include preserving data to help trace any problems and having AI systems clearly spell out their capabilities and limitations. Users should be told when they're interacting with a machine and not a human while humans should be in charge of the system and have the final say on decisions such as rejecting an application for welfare benefits, the report said.

EU leaders said they also wanted to open a debate on when to allow facial recognition in remote identification systems, which are used to scan crowds to check people's faces to those on a database. It's considered the "most intrusive form" of the technology and is prohibited in the EU except in special cases.

___

For all of the AP's technology coverage: https://apnews.com/apf-technology.

___
